column4: it's the main cd, it's the first link from the left, i really don't understand why people keep doubting that it's the "real" ubuntu cd :\
most operating systems don't install from a LiveCD :P
a few operating systems do install from a "live cd", although it isn't necessarily called a "live cd" since that's simply the way they've always been installed

livecd's are not commonly used for system installs, which is why a lot of people are confused.  Usually the LiveCD is used for testing whether the distribution will work at all, and then subsequent disc downloads allow for actual installation.

at any rate, the first line of the paragraph describing the Desktop CD (right where you download it) says "The desktop CD allows you to try Ubuntu without changing your computer at all, and at your option to install it permanently later."
agreed, but confusion abounds
barongas: or more likely cp -a blah blah
-R is a recursive copy and works fine ;)
why would you use "sudo su - root"?
he asked how to become root, and I answered him
yeah, except it doesn't preserve ownerships and it follows symlinks. not what you want normally
but that's a bad answer. "sudo -i" is a much better one
either way is fine
sudo -i has always been the very much recommended way on this channel and elsewhere in the ubuntu documentation. sudo su is redundant, at the very least
whatever
except that sudo just lets you execute a command as root, where su lets you become root.  If you don't know your root password, then sudo su is a viable solution.  Redundant? I think not.
eh? so, how *exactly* does "sudo -i" *not* let you become root?
I never said it didn't, but sudo su isn't redundant

i just explained to dura why it is. "sudo" is a command that changes your privileges. "su" is also a command that changes your privileges. using both is redundant, since sudo alone is perfectly sufficient.
it's just 2 different ways to accomplish the same thing
one of which is redundant, yes.
